Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They casually mention a religious story during a community gathering.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket as I stood in the center of the community hall, the hum of conversation swirling around me. I was in the middle of sharing the story of the Good Samaritan, hoping to spark a discussion about kindness and compassion. As I spoke, I felt the familiar vibration again—three times in quick succession. I knew it was my mother. She always texted around this time, wanting to hear about my day, asking for every little detail, expecting me to reply right away. I glanced at the screen: “Are you okay? Haven’t heard from you. Call me.” Guilt pricked at me. I was supposed to be fully present here, guiding my congregation, but my mother’s anxious messages tugged at my heart. I wanted to honor her need for connection, but I also needed to fulfill my calling as a pastor, to teach and lead without distraction. My words faltered for a moment as I wrestled with the impossible choice—answer my mother now, or continue serving my community.
